usa: Vietnam War: Johnson escalates United States military involvement in the war, with the number of U.S. troops totaling more than 184,000.[340]
African American Muslim minister and human rights activist Malcolm X was assassinated at the Audubon Ballroom in Harlem, New York.<sup id="cite_ref-378" class="reference">[378]</sup>
Operation Rolling Thunder began in the Vietnam War.[379]
The Selma to Montgomery marches, known as "Bloody Sunday", drew national outrage after Alabama State Troopers severely beat and used tear gas against the nonviolent demonstrators.[380]

In a third attempt to march from Selma to Montgomery, 3,200 civil rights demonstrators reached the Alabama State Capitol, where they were joined with a crowd of 25,000, after four days of marching.<sup id="cite_ref-381" class="reference">[381]</sup>

March Against the Vietnam War: The Students for a Democratic Society (SDS) and the SNCC led the first major anti-war demonstration against the Vietnam War in Washington, D.C., with over 25,000 protesters.[382]
The Social Security Amendments of 1965 was signed into law, establishing Medicaid and Medicare in the United States.<sup id="cite_ref-383" class="reference">[383]</sup>
The Voting Rights Act was signed into law.<sup id="cite_ref-384" class="reference">[384]</sup>
The Watts riots began in the Watts neighborhood of Los Angeles, resulting in the deaths of 34 people.[385]

The United States Department of Housing and Urban Development (HUD) was established, after the Housing and Urban Development Act of 1965 was signed into law by President Johnson.<sup id="cite_ref-386" class="reference">[386]</sup>
The Immigration Act of 1965 was signed into law, abolishing the National Origins Formula.<sup id="cite_ref-387" class="reference">[387]</sup>
The Higher Education Act of 1965 was passed.<sup id="cite_ref-388" class="reference">[388]</sup>
